posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

Given that the drug war and the prohibition of substances (e.g. alcohol) has been a failure why don't we legalize all drugs, include hard ones like heroin/opium, meth and cocaine?

Legalization would basically eliminate 90% of the revenue of organized crime groups like the Mexican cartel which would greatly diminish their power. Most of the problems that come from using drugs like heroin such as its price, low quality, needles infected with HIV/Hepatitis, and mixed potency (which leads to overdose) would be eliminated. You'd have high quality drugs made on a massive scale by trained and qualified chemist and pharmacologists in sanitary conditions with next to no impurities. People would know the dose they are getting and the quality would be super high, that and the price would be very cheap. People wouldn't have to resort to crime or illegal activities to finance their drug habit, they could afford it with a minimum wage job. This would also free up police resources and relieve the justice system of a large chunk of its cases.

The only ethical objection that I have come across, or what most of the objections offered boiled down to, is this vague Christcuck puritanical "be of sober mind" mentality. Where being in an altered state of mind is "ungodly". Now, prohibitionists don't use religious language, they are ostensibly secularist, but that's what they are saying ultimately amounts to. The idea that people are enjoying themselves in a way that they don't approve of upsets them.

posts.com:
>>14576260
Ribbentropp raised the possibility of the Soviet Union joining a new Four Power Pact. The conditions that Stalin laid out were unacceptable to the Germans. The demands being made at the time, in addition to Soviet complaints Germany's guarantee of Romanian territory contrary to their interests in Bukovina, represented clear dangers to German interests. Germany was already dependent, to an extent, on the resources the Soviet Union was providing for their war effort. The Soviet Union showed itself willing to withhold such shipments in the past only to reverse course after the German victories in Scandinavia shocked them. Allowing the Soviets to occupy Finland, southern Bukovina, and Bulgaria would further endanger Germany's resources and strategic position. These demands were also being made at the very height of Hitler's power in Europe making the required deference to the Soviet Union insulting - something Molotov's forceful manner in attempting to wrangle concessions out of Hitler intensified at the time. I am suspect if either Germany or the Soviet Union expected the other to concede to each other's conditions by the time Stalin sent his conditions in reply to Ribbentrop's offer, as such.

>>14572679
The Irish language continued to decline after independence for the same reasons that it declined while Ireland under British rule - English was the language of social prestige, while Irish was associated with rural poverty and backwardness and thus had a stigma attached to it. Due to a lack of employment in Irish-speaking areas, people living there would move to English speaking regions for seasonal work, where they would often endure mockery due to their broken English and incomprehensible accents. People therefore decided to make sure that their kids would never endure the same thing, by speaking only English to them, causing the language to die out across most areas. The government at one point tried to fix the issue by bringing industry to the remaining Irish speaking areas, but this only hastened the linguistic demise because as the locals weren't educated to staff the factories and facilities, English speaking workers from places like Dublin were brought in and this ended up only increasing the dominance of English in these regions.

If its not plastered over and the mixture (clay-sand-water) doesn't have the right ratio if falls to pieces rather quickly. I have worked with cob to make miniature Tudor houses and even a smoke house and its a wonderful material. It insulates well, doesn't rot, is extremely cheap and can be made almost anywhere (and was/is) and requires little in the way of tools, technological advancement or craftsmanship to get the bare minimum stuff like kilns going. The issue is that Africans are really shit at keeping things well kept and maintained. Look at pic rel and then look at a Tudor home or something from James Town or any traditional European/Asian/ME home. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Paganism wasn't really a religion in the same way Christianity was.

People didn't go every waking moment of their life thinking about what Zeus thought of their actions.
They would participate in the seasonal festivals and local traditions but only because that was the thing to do. They didn't think very strongly about them and many probably found them tedious.
They took the existence of the gods for granted and viewed the whole thing as just the way the world worked. It wasn't special.

But when Christianity came about, it demanded fervour. It demanded that you dedicate your life to Christ. It was more engaging.
But it was also more optimistic than Paganism. The Pagan life was not very uplifting, it demanded physical offerings, which cost money, it demanded that you be an ambitious and virtuous person not just internally but externally in the form of seeking wealth, fame, and glory. When you die from the Pagan point of view, unless you are some heroic emperor, if you're just an average joe, you are going to hell, because that's what the underworld is to them, very few people go to heaven.
Contrast with Christianity where all you have to do is believe in Christ and be a good person to yourself, and you will get to spend eternity in heaven. It's a much better offer.

Also, like so many things, Paganism was old and Christianity was new. The trendy elites following in the latest fashions sought to mock anyone who wasn't following Christianity as silly and uneducated, hence the name Paganism meaning of the country people.

And also jews

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14572915
All evidence points to the opposite: Pre-proto-Sino-Tibetan originated somewhere south of the Yellow River.

The Central Plain up to Shandong was inhabited by extinct pre-proto-Koryo-Japonic speakers before their displacement by Sino-Tibetans. Further north you had the proto-Hunno-Turkics living on the Eastern Steppe. Early proto-Mongolics and proto-Tungusics lived side by side in modern Manchuria, east of the Khingan and north of the Yan Mountains. This explains why all supposed Altaic language show great similarity. They had pre-historic contacts with each other and Sino-Tibetan is the odd one out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Would the world be a better place if the British Empire was still around?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14575032
That's a question that really depends on the circumstances. Did it continue more or less as it did in the early 20th century, with the cooperation of local peoples, or did the decolonization movement still happen and Britain only kept the empire through brutal repression?

Assuming the British Empire continued without descending into a permanent state of civil war, I would say it would definitely have benefitted the colonies themselves and the world in general. Corruption is the number one problem for most developing countries; Britain provided an administrative class that were both competent and honest. They were also fairly effective in dealing with security problems; unlike France or Portugal they were never forced out of any of their colonies by military action, suppressing revolts in Malaysia and Kenya fairly easily. Many of their former colonies had their development stymied after the British left by internal political struggles and civil wars.

There's also the point that India wouldn't have been partitioned, which would have been immensely beneficial for the subcontinent.

It still begs the question: in what form could the British Empire have survived? As I said above, continuing down the road it was on would have torn it apart eventually. However, I think that if London had ever seriously pursued the Imperial Federation idea, allowing the white colonies equal say in the government of the empire while granting local autonomy to the rest, they could have found a compromise that would produce a workable system.

The problem with the British Empire was not that the colonies were tired of it but that London was - and I say specifically London and the ruling class rather than Britain as a whole. Even in the 1930s the British elite seemed to think that empire had run its course and was coming to an end, while the empire itself still assumed it would go on forever. If the British leadership had shown any initiative or backbone, it might well have.

posts.com:
>If God is all good all loving all knowing and all powerful why does he allow so much pointless suffering to happen? Like rape, torture, genocide, birth defects, children with cancer, etc
The most common answer is “free will” but there are 3 huge problems with that

1. Omniscience Paradox
Strict Determinist: If God is all knowing we don’t have free will because he knows everything that we will do in the future, which means the future is predetermined. He already knows who will or will not die a sinner the moment they are born. If God is omniscient he already knows what he will do in the future too, which means he also lacks free will
Compatibilist: God can create a world where we theoretically could sin, but no one would actually want to do it so it never happens. However he hasn’t done that

2. Heaven and free will
If Heaven has free will then God is capable of creating a world of eternal bliss with no suffering, that also has free will, yet doesn’t do that

If Heaven lacks free will then free will isn’t particularly valuable. We will spend eternity with no free will anyways, our short lives with free will is working towards this as a goal. Religion portrays Heaven as a reward, something desirable, so it is admitting that an eternity of bliss with no free will is preferable over a short life filled with suffering with free will.

3. Degree of evil
God can create an exact replica of our current world, but make one heinous evil impossible to commit, like rape. We would still have free will and live in an objectively better world

If you object and say that isn’t free will, the rebuttal is God decides what is or isn’t possible. I can’t phase through walls or stop time in this world, does that mean I lack free will? Why can’t God just make rape impossible then?

> you don’t need the construct of religion or god to have a moral code
I agree, but the question was about the basis of that code, and how we can possibly decide which moral code is the right one. Like every person I naturally have impressions that certain things are right, others wrong, but it is just an impression based on some combination of social pressures and my natural temperament. If I were to get knocked in the head in the wrong place, maybe I'd become a psychopath.
>We have the law which is an actual force that is capable of doing something right now.
The law is based on conventions and some shared agreements about punishment for rule-breaking.
The law is not a source of morality, it is the product of us already having a sense of morality.
Our sense of morality I think personally is natural in-built due to our evolved social tendencies, but that baseline natural pro-sociality (towards our group) can get interpreted in many different ways depending on your social context.
The belief in God doesn't in reality provide an objective morality because we can observe in religious societies deep, often violent, disagreements as to how God's law ought to be interpreted. Not to mention that there are religious moralities that purport to be objective, but which concretely lead to nihilism (in the sense of total abandonment of concern for the tangible impact of their ideals on people's wellbeing).
The question we must tackle in the abscense of a God is how to justify our own moral notions over and against other society's moral conventions. Can you convincingly argue that the Aztec practice of ritual sacrifice is inherently morally wrong if morals are nothing more than a human creation. Or is your attitude that sacrificing people is wrong, nothing more than a social convention?
Why should I believe in human rights?

posts.com:
William the Conqueror's army comprised not only Normans, but also Bretons, Flemings and soldiers from all over Northern France. And from the Angevin dynasty onwards, nobles from the whole of France, north and south alike, would migrate to England due to the multinational nature of the Angevin Empire (hence the prevalence of names like Gascoigne that refer to places outside of Normandy).
Primary sources from the period don't use the word Anglo-Norman either, the History of William Marshal just calls the French-speaking nobility of England "Engleis" and distinguishes them from the continental Normans.
There are even cases of Anglo-Norman nobles owning land on both sides of the Channel, even after Philip II's conquest of Normandy, for example the Parisian de Montfort family which founded the English Parliament.
To me it doesn't seem that Anglo-Normans ever existed. Normans may have made up the majority among the imported French nobility early on, but fast forward 60 years later and you've got Richard I, a king whose native languages were the Angevin dialect of Old French and Old Occitan.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14569343
>let's name it however we want
I can understand using a foreign cognomen when speaking of a civilization whose proper self-name isn't known or is of dubious use (for example, the Rasenna civilization, more known as the Etruscans, or pre-writing civilization like pre-Cuzco Andean civilizations), but the Romans or "Rhomaioi", if you want to absolutely be pedantic about distinguishing the Western Romans from their Eastern, more hellenized counterparts, clearly considered themselves Romans in each and every situation in which they described themselves. To dismiss that name because of some insignificant crusade to separate them from the greater Roman World - because it *is* insignificant, considering their political institutions are simply reforms upon reforms on the Dominate system which defined the Late Roman Empire and its Eastern split - is nothing more than the perpetuation of a vilification campaign from actors long dead, whether the Holy Roman Empire of the German Nation or later claimants like the Russian Tsardom.
The only acceptable names for the Basileia ton Rhomaion are :
>Basileia ton Rhomaion/Imperium Romanorum: "The Empire of the Romans
>Arche ton Rhomaion : "The Rulership of the Romans
>Romania/Rhomania : "Land of the Romans"
>Rhomais : "Rome"
Furthermore, to call it the Kingdom of the Greeks would be stupid and insulting: those that would drag down the Empire's reputation would call Greeks a population which did not recognize itself as such, forgetting that Rhomaioi did not consider themselves Greeks but Romans, and spoke "Roman" ("Romaiika") between each others.
If anything, the opposite is the truth : Greek identity was a construct forged upon the remain of the Eastern Roman identity, and subsumed it entirely.

>>14569521
Easy. They don't really do it anymore, but societies all over the world until modern times used horrible torture as a punishment for crimes. You can argue that what we do today--incarceration or extremely humane execution--isn't a "horrific crime" (that is kind of a vague term but I'm trying not to get into philosophy here), but I'm sure most people participating in public judicial torture in the Middle Ages would agree that it was horrific, and probably, other than a few sadists, didn't relish doing it. But they would have believed that it prevented crime in the society via deterrence, so they would consider it a necessary evil and do it anyway. Hell, if you were very religious, you might believe that burning a witch was a necessary evil to protect the society from the witch's curses and the wrath of God, even though you didn't enjoy setting a pretty young woman on fire.

Shit like breaking at the wheel, burning at the stake, drawing and quartering in Europe, or death by a thousand cuts or some of the other nasty shit they did to people in China, were all done with a good rationale of deterring crime and protecting the royalty of the state to prevent anarchy and chaos. I don't believe they were all sadistic bastards, most of them were probably holding their nose and doing it reluctantly because the really believed it was the right way to maintain a stable society.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Party politics temporarily disappeared with the demise of the Federalists. In 1824 there were no parties but instead several regional presidential candidates--Andrew Jackson, John Quincy Adams, Henry Clay, and William Crawford. The Virginian Crawford had the endorsement of former presidents Jefferson and Madison, but suffered a stroke and had to drop out halfway through the race. Since there was no statutory election day in the United States until 1848, elections in this time took place over a period of months. When the electoral votes were counted on the floor of the Senate in February 1825 by outgoing Vice President Daniel Tompkins, Jackson received 99 of them and carried the Mid-Atlantic, most of the South, and part of the West. Adams with 84 votes carried his backyard in New England and New York, Crawford (despite dropping out of the race) won his home state and Georgia with 41, and Clay won his home state along with Ohio and Missouri for 37 electoral votes.

Unfortunately the four-way contest meant no candidate received a majority of electoral votes, thus the election was to be decided by the House of Representatives. Henry Clay abandoned his presidential bid and urged support among colleagues for Adams, as he despised Jackson and felt more ideological compatibility with the dour Secretary of State. The House voted to confirm Adams as president, although he had won a mere 33% of the popular vote and almost all of that came from one section of the country. Andrew Jackson had received the most popular votes of the four candidates and condemned the "Adams-Clay Corrupt Bargain", believing he'd been robbed. He almost immediately began making plans for another run in 1828 and came to support the idea of abolishing the Electoral College and electing the president by direct popular vote.

Five states in 1824 had no direct popular vote and had their electors chosen by the state legislature. Six used a district-based system.

>The age of the Founding Fathers was coming to a close by the 1820s. Thomas Jefferson and John Adams both died within a few hours of each other on July 4, 1826, the nation's 50th birthday, and a new generation of men such as Henry Clay and Daniel Webster came to dominate American politics. The second president's son meanwhile took the oath of office on March 4, 1825. Symbolizing the new era, John Quincy Adams was the first president to wear pants instead of breeches, and to not sport powdered hair and a ponytail. The new president was a brilliant intellect, but an unlovable and dour man whose elitist, Federalist views seemed out of touch with growing mass democracy--he enjoyed walks alone or nude swims in the Potomac River. Adams renewed George Washington's call for a national academy, Federal infrastructure spending, and even a series of astronomical observatories to rival those of Europe.

>For all his success as SoS, Adams's foreign policy record was remarkably poor. Ever since the 1783 Treaty of Paris, Britain had barred American merchant vessels from her Caribbean islands, although ingenious Yankee smugglers managed to often get through anyway. Adams brusquely demanded that London open the islands to American trade. Foreign Secretary Lord Canning curtly refused. In 1826, the newly independent Latin American states held a Conference of the Americas in Panama City, and Adams decided to send representatives over the objection of Southern states who loathed the idea of recognizing the "black and mixed republics" of Latin America as their equal. The conference dissolved without accomplishing anything significant, and one US representative died en route to it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14572529
The depiction of novels and movies is generally untrue.
"Treasure Island" isn't actually a bad representation of the politics of a pirate crew. While the captain was generally democratically elected his position was linked directly to the successes he was able to generate. A unsuccessful would be replaced and either integrated back into the crew (with a severely damaged reputation), exiled or killed. This can be seen in the fictional character of Long John Silver, whose position as leader is raver precarious.
Another aspect of pirate fantasy are the ships themselves: most pirates had a sloops at best. The ones with bigger ships (like Blackbeard) stand out because they were the exception.
And lastly: life as a pirate was horrible. Maritime travel of this time period was generally unpleasant and pirates took it to the extreme since they packed even more men into a limited space. They also were not after gold but trade wares and provisions because gold, ironically, would be rather worthless to them.

>Venetian and Genoese merchants had their own neighborhoods in the cities of Cilician Armenia, including consulates, churches, courthouses, bath houses, warehouses etc.[16] The most progressive technologies of trade of the time were actively used in Cilicia. The spread of paper in the Mediterranean had changed the nature of trade. Merchant could sail from Ayas with only a promissory note or receipt, without any hard money, to any other Mediterranean city such as Barcelona. There, he could present the receipt, receive goods and sail back to Ayas to sell them. Many Genoese and Venetian notary agents had established themselves in Cilician Armenia. The documents they prepared, which sometimes could weigh several kilos, reached Italian cities despite the limited capacity of medieval ships. Hundreds of merchants and other professionals from Genoa, Venice, Southern France and Catalonia are included in those notary transactions.
